question_details.query: To protect newly planted trees from herbivores, what is the evidence for the effectiveness of fencing compared to using individual tree guards or shelters?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence for individual guards/shelters: One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that light-coloured plastic tree shelters increased survival of planted tree seedlings, whereas dark-coloured shelters did not [1268]. One replicated, controlled study in Hong Kong found that tree guards increased tree height after 37 months but not after 44 months [1268]. In exposed coastal sites in the USA, full-length plastic shelters for red mangrove increased survival over 4–8 months, while full-length bamboo shelters and below-ground plastic shelters had no clear effect; plastic shelters also produced taller propagules in three of four comparisons over 22–129 days [3331]. In a nutria-invaded freshwater wetland in the USA, plastic guards on planted baldcypress increased height and diameter growth over one growing season [3330]. Evidence for fencing/exclosure: In a USA floodplain swamp clearing, fencing to exclude deer did not change total tree seedling density after three years in plots sown with tree seeds, but fenced plots contained taller seedlings after three years than unfenced plots [3330]. In created freshwater wetlands in the USA, white cedar sapling height typically increased by a similar amount in fenced and unfenced plots over two to five years [3330]. In Australian floodplain swamps, plots fenced to exclude mammals had much higher one-year survival of planted swamp gum seedlings than open plots [3330]. Two USA freshwater wetland studies reported that exclusion fencing sometimes increased survival of planted tree seedlings and sometimes had no clear or significant effect, depending on planting season, elevation, and site [3330]. Gaps: No studies were found that evaluated fences or barriers to protect planted peatland vegetation [1839].
summary_statements: A study in the USA found that light-coloured plastic tree shelters increased survival of planted tree seedlings.
The same USA study found that dark-coloured shelters did not increase the survival of planted tree seedlings.
A study in Hong Kong found that tree guards increased tree height after 37 months.
The same Hong Kong study found that tree guards did not increase tree height after 44 months.
In exposed coastal sites in the USA, full-length plastic shelters for red mangrove increased survival over 4–8 months.
In exposed coastal sites in the USA, full-length bamboo shelters had no clear effect on red mangrove survival.
In exposed coastal sites in the USA, below-ground plastic shelters had no clear effect on red mangrove survival.
In exposed coastal sites in the USA, plastic shelters produced taller red mangrove propagules in three of four comparisons over 22–129 days.
In a nutria-invaded freshwater wetland in the USA, plastic guards on planted baldcypress increased height and diameter growth over one growing season.
In a USA floodplain swamp clearing, fencing to exclude deer did not change total tree seedling density after three years in plots sown with tree seeds.
In a USA floodplain swamp clearing, fenced plots contained taller seedlings after three years than unfenced plots.
In created freshwater wetlands in the USA, white cedar sapling height typically increased by a similar amount in fenced and unfenced plots over two to five years.
In Australian floodplain swamps, plots fenced to exclude mammals had much higher one-year survival of planted swamp gum seedlings than open plots.
Two USA freshwater wetland studies reported that exclusion fencing sometimes increased survival of planted tree seedlings.
Two USA freshwater wetland studies reported that exclusion fencing sometimes had no clear or significant effect on the survival of planted tree seedlings.
The effectiveness of exclusion fencing on planted tree seedling survival depended on planting season, elevation, and site.
No studies were found that evaluated fences or barriers to protect planted peatland vegetation.

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of removing competing understory vegetation on planted trees and overall forest biodiversity?
In degraded forest areas, what interventions are available to improve soil conditions and enhance tree growth?
What is the state of the evidence regarding the effectiveness of managing public access and tourism to mitigate human disturbance in forests?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on managing public access to reduce wildlife disturbance includes: a replicated, paired sites, site comparison study in the USA reporting that removing or closing roads increased use of those areas by black bears [2325]; six studies from multiple regions reporting increased numbers of breeders, higher reproductive success, or lower disturbance in waders and terns following access restrictions or signage near nesting areas, with one USA before-and-after study successfully relocating a heron colony to an area with no public access, though one European study on eagles and one replicated, controlled Antarctic study on penguins found no effect [309]. Evidence gaps include: no studies found on the effects of restricting pedestrian access on vegetation in marshes or swamps [3022]; no studies found on using voluntary agreements with locals to reduce disturbance for mammals [2339]; and no evidence on the effects of prohibiting food consumption where primates can view people [1508]. Tourism-related evidence includes two studies on reptile-focused eco-tourism reporting self-reported human behaviour changes (participants indicating they would have searched for nesting turtles without supervised tours, or increased conscientiousness about behaviours affecting sea turtles) [3680].
summary_statements: A replicated, paired sites, site comparison study in the USA reported that removing or closing roads increased the use of those areas by black bears.

Six studies from multiple regions reported increased numbers of breeders, higher reproductive success, or lower disturbance in waders and terns following access restrictions or signage near nesting areas.
One USA before-and-after study successfully relocated a heron colony to an area with no public access.
One European study on eagles and one replicated, controlled Antarctic study on penguins found no effect from managing public access.
No studies were found on the effects of restricting pedestrian access on vegetation in marshes or swamps.
No studies were found on using voluntary agreements with local people to reduce disturbance for mammals.
There is no evidence on the effects of prohibiting food consumption where primates can view people.
Two studies on reptile-focused eco-tourism reported self-reported human behaviour changes.
Participants in reptile-focused eco-tourism indicated they would have searched for nesting turtles without supervised tours.
Participants in reptile-focused eco-tourism reported increased conscientiousness about behaviours affecting sea turtles.

question_details.query: How does the effectiveness of managing livestock grazing to protect forests vary across different geographical locations mentioned in the evidence?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across locations, effects vary: Preventing livestock grazing increased survival, species richness and diversity of understory plants in Brazil, the UK and Costa Rica, with one study reporting mixed effects; in Israel, preventing cattle grazing increased oak seedling and sapling density (1206). Excluding livestock with wire fences increased understory biomass, species richness, density and cover in some studies from Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Israel, New Zealand, Spain, West Africa and the USA, while other studies in these regions found mixed or no effects; in Mexico, Kenya, Israel and Panama, fencing increased the size, density and number of regenerating trees, though one study reported decreased tree density without a change in tree size (1205). Shortening the grazing period increased abundance and size of regenerating oak in Spain, had no effect on native plant species richness in Australia, and in the UK resulted in higher numbers of tree seedlings after summer than winter grazing (1208). Reducing grazing intensity increased tree saplings in the UK and increased understory biomass in Greece (1207).
summary_statements: Preventing livestock grazing increased the survival, species richness, and diversity of understory plants in Brazil, the UK, and Costa Rica.
One study on preventing livestock grazing reported mixed effects on understory plants.
In Israel, preventing cattle grazing increased oak seedling and sapling density.

Excluding livestock with wire fences increased understory biomass, species richness, density, and cover in some studies from Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Israel, New Zealand, Spain, West Africa, and the USA.
Other studies in Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Israel, New Zealand, Spain, West Africa, and the USA found mixed or no effects from excluding livestock.
In Mexico, Kenya, Israel, and Panama, fencing increased the size, density, and number of regenerating trees.
One study reported that fencing decreased tree density without a change in tree size.
Shortening the grazing period increased the abundance and size of regenerating oak in Spain.
Shortening the grazing period had no effect on native plant species richness in Australia.
In the UK, shortening the grazing period resulted in higher numbers of tree seedlings after summer grazing compared to winter grazing.
Reducing grazing intensity increased tree saplings in the UK.
Reducing grazing intensity increased understory biomass in Greece.

question_details.query: What management techniques involving tree removal can be used to increase forest structural diversity and what are their effects?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence-based, tree-removal techniques include: group-selection harvesting, general logging/removal, partial retention harvesting, and clearcutting. Group-selection harvesting increased understory plant cover and diversity and the density of young trees in multiple studies, though some studies reported decreases or no effects on understory metrics and tree density/growth-rate [1224]. General logging/removal increased understory plant density and cover in about half of studies and increased understory species richness/diversity in several studies, while other studies found no or mixed effects [1273]; it increased young tree density in one replicated controlled study and showed mixed effects in another [1272]; for mature trees, logging decreased tree density/cover in some studies, increased density in others, had mixed effects on tree size (increases in several studies; decreases or no effect in others), and showed mixed effects on tree species richness/diversity, with decreases in some studies and increases or no effect in others [1271]; among non-vascular plants, logging decreased epiphyte abundance and fern fertility in two of three studies, with species-specific mixed effects reported elsewhere [1270]. Partial retention harvesting (vs clearcutting) decreased the density of young trees in three Canadian studies [1215]. Clearcutting increased understory plant cover and species richness in most of the studies reviewed, but reduced density, species richness, and diversity of mature trees in some studies; effects on young tree density/species richness were mixed across studies [1222].
summary_statements: Evidence-based, tree-removal techniques include group-selection harvesting, general logging/removal, partial retention harvesting, and clearcutting.
Group-selection harvesting increased understory plant cover and diversity in multiple studies.
Group-selection harvesting increased the density of young trees in multiple studies.
Some studies reported that group-selection harvesting caused decreases or had no effects on understory metrics and tree density or growth-rate.
General logging/removal increased understory plant density and cover in about half of studies.
General logging/removal increased understory species richness and diversity in several studies.
Some studies found that general logging/removal had no or mixed effects on understory plants.
General logging/removal increased young tree density in one replicated controlled study and showed mixed effects in another.
For mature trees, logging decreased tree density and cover in some studies, while increasing density in others.
Logging had mixed effects on mature tree size, causing increases in several studies and decreases or no effect in others.
Logging showed mixed effects on tree species richness and diversity, with decreases in some studies and increases or no effect in others.
Among non-vascular plants, logging decreased epiphyte abundance and fern fertility in two of three studies.
When compared to clearcutting, partial retention harvesting decreased the density of young trees in three Canadian studies.
Clearcutting increased understory plant cover and species richness in most of the studies reviewed.
Clearcutting reduced the density, species richness, and diversity of mature trees in some studies.
The effects of clearcutting on young tree density and species richness were mixed across studies.

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of thinning trees on the various components of a forest ecosystem, including mature trees, young trees, and understory plants?
Based on studies from the USA, what is the effectiveness of applying different chemical treatments to protect tree seedlings?
To avoid the impacts of clearcutting in European and North American forests, what are the documented effects of alternative harvesting methods like shelterwood or partial retention harvesting?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies in North America and Europe, shelterwood harvesting compared to clearcutting was associated with: higher macro‑moth species richness than patch‑cutting or clearcutting and faster post‑harvest recovery of moth richness than group selection or clearcutting, with moth richness sometimes similar to single‑tree, group selection, or clearcutting and lower than unharvested forest (USA; 3 studies) [3871]; salamander abundance that was higher, similar, or initially higher then similar relative to clearcutting, and a North American meta‑analysis found partial harvest (including shelterwood among other types) caused smaller salamander population reductions than clearcutting; however, relative to no harvest, shelterwood sometimes decreased salamander abundance and altered species composition, and some reproductive metrics were similar or lower depending on species and time since harvest (USA; multiple studies and meta‑analysis) [851]; and higher plant diversity, lower grass cover, and higher density of tree species than clearcutting (Sweden and USA; 3 replicated, controlled studies) [1214]. Partial retention harvesting, compared to clearcutting, decreased the density of young trees in studies from Canada (including one replicated, randomized, controlled study) [1215].
summary_statements: Compared to patch-cutting or clearcutting, shelterwood harvesting was associated with higher macro-moth species richness.
Shelterwood harvesting was associated with a faster post-harvest recovery of moth richness than group selection or clearcutting.
Moth richness with shelterwood harvesting was sometimes similar to single-tree, group selection, or clearcutting.
Moth richness with shelterwood harvesting was sometimes lower than in unharvested forest.
Salamander abundance under shelterwood harvesting was higher, similar, or initially higher then became similar relative to clearcutting.
A North American meta-analysis found partial harvest, including shelterwood, caused smaller salamander population reductions than clearcutting.
Relative to no harvest, shelterwood harvesting sometimes decreased salamander abundance.
Relative to no harvest, shelterwood harvesting sometimes altered salamander species composition.
Some salamander reproductive metrics under shelterwood harvesting were similar or lower than in unharvested areas, depending on the species and time since harvest.
Shelterwood harvesting was associated with higher plant diversity than clearcutting.
Shelterwood harvesting was associated with lower grass cover than clearcutting.
Shelterwood harvesting was associated with a higher density of tree species than clearcutting.
Partial retention harvesting, compared to clearcutting, decreased the density of young trees.

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence regarding different methods for restoring forests by adding or encouraging biological material like seeds, plants, or beneficial organisms?
To aid the establishment of newly planted trees in a restoration project, what actions are available to protect them from competition and other threats?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Using tree guards or shelters: light-coloured plastic shelters increased survival of planted tree seedlings, while dark-coloured did not; tree guards increased tree height after 37 months but not after 44 months [1268].
- Covering ground with plastic mats after planting: decreased cover of herbaceous plants and grasses [1239].
- Covering ground using techniques other than plastic mats (e.g., mulch): increased total plant cover after planting [1240].
- Fencing to prevent grazing after planting: in four of five studies, exclusion increased survival, size and cover of planted trees; two studies found no effect on survival; one study found mixed effects on planted tree size depending on fence structure [1254].
- Mechanical/manual removal of invasive plants: increased understory plant biomass in one study; no effect on understory plant diversity in another; increased tree seedling height in one study; no effect on growth rate of native species in another [1228].
summary_statements: Light-coloured plastic shelters increased the survival of planted tree seedlings.
Dark-coloured plastic shelters did not increase the survival of planted tree seedlings.
Tree guards increased tree height after 37 months.
Tree guards did not increase tree height after 44 months.
Covering the ground with plastic mats after planting decreased the cover of herbaceous plants and grasses.
Covering the ground using techniques other than plastic mats, such as mulch, increased total plant cover after planting.
In four of five studies, fencing to prevent grazing after planting increased the survival, size, and cover of planted trees.
Two studies found that fencing to prevent grazing after planting had no effect on the survival of planted trees.
One study found fencing to prevent grazing after planting had mixed effects on planted tree size depending on the fence structure.
Mechanical or manual removal of invasive plants increased understory plant biomass in one study.
Mechanical or manual removal of invasive plants had no effect on understory plant diversity in another study.
Mechanical or manual removal of invasive plants increased tree seedling height in one study.
Mechanical or manual removal of invasive plants had no effect on the growth rate of native species in another study.

question_details.query: In the USA, what are the documented effects of different post-harvesting management techniques on young trees and understory vegetation?
As an alternative to using herbicides, what other methods can be used to control vegetation competition for seedlings and young trees?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents identifies several non-chemical methods to manage competing vegetation around seedlings and young trees: mechanically removing understory vegetation after planting (e.g., removing competing herbs increased seedling biomass in one study; removing sheep laurel shrubs increased growth rate and height of planted black spruce) [1256]; covering the ground with plastic mats after restoration planting, which decreased cover of herbaceous plants and grasses [1239]; using weed mats to protect planted trees, which in one replicated, controlled study did not change thick-leaved oak seedling height [1267]; and adding cover such as plastic or jute mats before planting in freshwater wetlands, which reduced cover of two problematic herb species and had no significant effect on overall shrub cover, swamp gum cover, or seedling height after one year [3318].
summary_statements: Several non-chemical methods can be used to manage competing vegetation around seedlings and young trees.
One non-chemical method to manage competing vegetation is to mechanically remove understory vegetation after planting.
Removing competing herbs increased seedling biomass in one study.
Removing sheep laurel shrubs increased the growth rate and height of planted black spruce.
Covering the ground with plastic mats after restoration planting decreased the cover of herbaceous plants and grasses.
Using weed mats to protect planted trees did not change the height of thick-leaved oak seedlings in one replicated, controlled study.
Adding cover such as plastic or jute mats before planting in freshwater wetlands reduced the cover of two problematic herb species.
Adding cover such as plastic or jute mats before planting in freshwater wetlands had no significant effect on overall shrub cover, swamp gum cover, or seedling height after one year.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of different forest management interventions studied in Australia?
How do mechanical removal and herbicide application compare in their effectiveness for controlling understory vegetation after tree planting?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Mechanical removal after tree planting: Five studies (including three replicated, randomized, controlled studies) in Canada, the USA, France, Panama, and Sweden found no effect of controlling understory vegetation on the emergence, survival, growth rate, or frost damage in planted seedlings; one study found removing competing herbs increased seedling biomass; one replicated, controlled study in Canada found removal of sheep laurel shrubs increased the growth rate and height of planted black spruce seedlings [1256]. Herbicide application after tree planting: Two of three studies (including two replicated, randomized, controlled studies) in Sweden and the USA found herbicide use increased the size of planted trees, while one study found no effect; one replicated, randomized, controlled study in Sweden found no effect of herbicide on frost damage to planted Norway spruce seedlings [1262].
summary_statements: Five studies found no effect of controlling understory vegetation on the emergence, survival, growth rate, or frost damage in planted seedlings.
One study found that removing competing herbs increased seedling biomass.
A replicated, controlled study in Canada found that the removal of sheep laurel shrubs increased the growth rate and height of planted black spruce seedlings.
Two of three studies in Sweden and the USA found herbicide use increased the size of planted trees.
One study found that herbicide use had no effect on the size of planted trees.
A replicated, randomized, controlled study in Sweden found no effect of herbicide on frost damage to planted Norway spruce seedlings.

question_details.query: What are the observed effects of adding soil amendments or ground coverings, such as organic matter, lime, or straw, after tree planting?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- In freshwater wetlands planted with trees/shrubs, adding large amounts of below-ground compost shifted plant communities toward those characteristic of drier conditions and reduced plant species richness and diversity after three years; overall vegetation biomass was similar to unamended plots, while birch Betula saplings were larger with high compost doses [3310].
- Adding lime to soil after tree planting decreased survival of planted pine seedlings in one study, while a separate study reported no effect of lime on the growth of planted oak seedlings [1259].
- In floodplain swamps, applying woodchip surface mulch before planting native shrubs did not change overall shrub cover after one year, did not affect swamp gum Eucalyptus camphora cover or height, and reduced the cover of problematic herb species in one of two swamps [3314].
- For brackish/saline wetlands, no studies were found that evaluated mulching in sites planted with trees/shrubs [3315].
summary_statements: In freshwater wetlands planted with trees or shrubs, adding large amounts of below-ground compost shifted plant communities toward those characteristic of drier conditions.
In freshwater wetlands planted with trees or shrubs, adding large amounts of below-ground compost reduced plant species richness and diversity after three years.
In freshwater wetlands, overall vegetation biomass was similar between plots with added below-ground compost and unamended plots.
In freshwater wetlands, birch Betula saplings were larger with high compost doses.
Adding lime to soil after tree planting decreased the survival of planted pine seedlings in one study.
A separate study reported no effect of lime on the growth of planted oak seedlings.
In floodplain swamps, applying woodchip surface mulch before planting native shrubs did not change the overall shrub cover after one year.
In floodplain swamps, applying woodchip surface mulch before planting did not affect swamp gum Eucalyptus camphora cover or height.
Applying woodchip surface mulch before planting native shrubs in floodplain swamps reduced the cover of problematic herb species in one of two swamps.
For brackish or saline wetlands, no studies were found that evaluated mulching in sites planted with trees or shrubs.

question_details.query: What is the evidence on the long-term effectiveness of using tree guards to protect planted trees?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that light-coloured plastic tree shelters increased survival of planted seedlings, whereas dark-coloured shelters did not [1268]. A replicated, controlled study in Hong Kong found that tree guards increased tree height after 37 months but not after 44 months [1268]. No studies were found that evaluated the effects of using tree tubes, small fences or cages to protect individual trees from mammals [2630].
summary_statements: A replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that light-coloured plastic tree shelters increased survival of planted seedlings.
A replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that dark-coloured shelters did not increase the survival of planted seedlings.
A replicated, controlled study in Hong Kong found that tree guards increased tree height after 37 months.
A replicated, controlled study in Hong Kong found that tree guards did not increase tree height after 44 months.
No studies were found that evaluated the effects of using tree tubes, small fences or cages to protect individual trees from mammals.
